the-invalid-user 15-Mar-20 12:22 AM
At first, it was peaceful, blissful, pitch-black, dreamless, sleep. No dreams, no nightmare, just a recharging of one's battery after going at 110% constantly for.. Well, for as long as they had been to New Romulus. Of course, his peace eventually ended, and Tor found himself... Back at the outskirts, where they had the first firefight with the Tal Shiar. He was gripping his rifle, down at cover, but he wasn't surrounded by the first tactical team he had gone down with. He was with his crew. Not the crew of the Phoenix, but of the Salvator, and they all looked scared, more than he felt. He tried to shake the feeling away, and poke out, only to be met with phaser fire, and was forced back down to his cover... Maniacal laughter rang out, and in the distant, Tor could hear screams, explosions, more phaser fire... Once again, he dared to poke his nose out, and for the brief moment, he saw the sky, which had turned a bloodish red, but that wasn't what had caught his attention. It was the ships. Dozens of carbon copies of the Arrinthe, descending down on New Romulus, and the Phoenix... It was gone. All he could see was the wreckage of the remains of the ship, slowly beginning to hit orbit. Phaser fire forced him back into his cover, but he poked out once again, and returned fire, encouraging those around him to do so as well. Someone came up next to him, pumping the trigger, and when Tor glanced over, he froze. Her. That wasn't possible. She must have caught his frozen stare, as she turned to him, and whispered, "I'm sorry," before aiming her weapon at him. Tor could almost tell that the rifle was set to kill, but before she could, she collapsed, and the girl, T'Diri, appeared in her place, a steely gaze on her face. Tor didn't even get a chance to thank her before phaser fire continued, and she disappeared as he was consumed by conflict once more.
- It felt like days as they fought. He couldn't see his enemies, and his allies had all disappeared, though Tor thought he could still hear them in the distance. He was pumping the trigger as much as he could, but none of them hit. As he ducked back to cover once more, something changed. He heard someone approaching. He steeled his nerves, and as they approached, leaped up, and went to smash the person with the butt of the rifle.. But they had anticipated the move. He finally got to his enemy, as he struggled to regain possession of his weapon. It was some kind of mushroom-head monster, the only part of the body untouched was the mouth... But the teeth had grown out, and a green fluid had begun leaking out. It's arms had morphed into nearly logs, but it still had strength inside of it, and just being near it made Tor feel weak. They wrestled for a few moments, as this hopeless battle raged on, before Tor got the upper hand, and knocked the thing's feet out from under it, and gripping his rifle, pointed it at the creature, before it transformed into the Admiral, laughing as the Romulan spat out blood. "You want to end it? End me!" The Romulan declared, still laughing. "Surely my tall, thin, handsome friend can do that, to save everyone!" Tor looked at his rifle's setting... Maximum stun. It had to be maximum stun. But right before his eyes, as if the rifle was listening to the mad Admiral, changed to kill. His pointer finger curled around the trigger as the weapon aimed at Valdain, and before Tor could stop and think, it transformed once more. The rifle, the Starfleet regulated phaser, transformed into an elongated version of the Tal Shiar pistol they had captured, the crystal gleaming, as if eagerly anticipating use a random sort of energy to end this madman's reign. (edited)
- But Tor didn't pull the trigger. Valdain laughed and laughed, the battle raged all around him, and the Arrinthe and it's carbon-copy sisters continued their descents, but he couldn't do it. He tried to think of what this man had done, of the atrocities that this man had done, the children he had sent to become a mushroom alien, the creation of T'Diri, the civil war he had brought upon these people, but, he couldn't do it. He couldn't end this madman, just like he couldn't eat meat. He could not take a life. Sweat poured out of him by the gallons, as he stared deep into the Admiral's eyes, which had turned green by this time, but he could not do it. The laughing stopped, as the Admiral stared back up at the Kelpein, and opened his mouth, as if he was going to taunt him, before a phaser bolt stopped the laughter, once and for all, and looking wildly, Tor's eyes landed upon her. She had gotten up, but she looked weak, but she had been strong enough to kill him. But as the pair locked eyes, the battle continued to rage. Surely it would end. Valdain had said it would en- An explosion rocked Tor off his feet, forcing him to collapse next to the Admiral. All he could hear was the ringing, as he struggled back to his feet, but the building he had been in, where his allies had been in, where she had been in, was gone. He could see bodies, but not faces. He couldn't stand to see their faces. Supporting himself on a wall, he grabbed his rifle, and slowly made his way to the middle of the battlefield, passing more and more bodies. He didn't know what he was searching for. He couldn't have known. Phaser fire flew over his head, past his arms, by his feet, but it never touched him. (edited)
- At the very center of the conflict, Tor finally saw what he had been walking to. A beam of pure blue light, where a crowd had gathered. The battle was rushing around them, as the last remnants of hope collapsed, but this crowd did not disperse, and the fighters did not disturb them, but Tor did. He pushed through the crowd, and began recognizing faces. Their uniforms were signed, and blood had covered them, but he recognized them nonetheless. The crew of the Phoenix. Steeling himself, he continued to push through, before finding the center, where a woman lied, next to a wheelchair. She looked almost like a stranger, someone Tor couldn't have remembered, but it was the Commodore. He knew that much. His legs collapsed under him, and he was forced to kneel by the body. He knew he had to say something, if not for the Commodore, but for the crew, but he didn't have anything. His throat was stuck, and his mind was blank. He had nothing. Tor sat up, bathed in sweat, panting. Pushing his feet out of bed, he supported himself on the wall, leaning on it as he walked over to the replicator. "Water. Glass." He croaked out, and as a glass of water appeared, he grabbed it, and drank it greedily, setting the glass down by his bed, and walking over to his desk, and checked the time. He still had some time before the wake. Grunting, he walked into his bathroom, and took a sonic shower. It was relieving to feel the sweat fall off his body, drying him, and left the shower cleaned. He grabbed the dress uniform, and pulled it on, straightening it as he looked at the hand phasers and tricorder, laying on the night-desk by his bed, before turning, and leaving them. He didn't need them. Certainly not anytime soon.

the-invalid-user 25-Mar-20 04:27 PM
Stumbling into his quarters, Tor set the bottle down at his deck, and fell upon the messy bed, Tor ensnared himself inside the blanket, and stared up at the ceiling, his eyes flickering, as he slowly fell asleep... With the capsule of medicine closed, unused since last night, sitting on his night-table, forgotten in his drunken state. It started immediately this time. He was plunged into the Phoenix's bridge, and, initially, it was quite peaceful. He was at his station, with his ACTOs (that he knew of this far), were beside him, but it was strange, almost. Everyone he knew was here with him, and even some people he didn't know, but had seen, were amongst the crowd. However, the bridge didn't feel cramped, if anything, it felt stretched and warped, to accommodate the amount of people there. He wasn't even sure that some of the people up there were supposed to be up there. Colonists, medical staff, even enemies, were up there, but they didn't pay him any mind. They were all absorbed in something... Well, most of them did. There were a few people that were walking around, talking with one another, and made the only noise in an otherwise dead silent room. Glancing between his console, and the people, Tor was about to stand up when he caught a glimpse of images from the console, and focused on it. Memories. The console had his memories. Smiling, Tor leaned in, looking into it, as memories flashed past. His time at the academy. The parties he went to... Then he grew older. The courses grew harder. He grew more secluded, isolated... But he graduated, and he got onto a starship... Chuckling, he watched as the young him explored the stars, helped people, and cared for people. He could almost feel young again, carefree, feel the scars and wisdom that came from age float away... But the memories finally returned to where it always went. The Salvator. He was helping colonists, with people he knew, cared for...
-- But they continued, and it finally arrived. Her. It was nice to look at, at first. The pair of them talking during their breaks, brushing past one another on their way to change shifts. Tor wasn't entirely sure why she had an interest in him. After all, Kelpiens weren't exactly well-known for their looks. Perhaps it was his charming jokes (unlikely), or his kindness, or maybe it was just because he trusted her, so easily, like he had been meant to do so. Others were suspicious, even cruel to her, but as the pair of them grew closer, the remarks they had so openly said about her slowly faded away, and those who had said them grew almost invisible, or slowly grew to like the girl, thanks to Tor. He had acted like a bridge for her, to connect her to everyone else, and it had worked. By the time the pair of them began dating, she had become friends with everyone he was friends with, which was the majority of the ship. Their first date was interesting, to say the least. He had to work up the courage to ask her out, gathering up support from his friends, and when he had finally arranged for it all to occur.. She had asked him. Ironic, was the word he believed that fit the situation. They had gone to the lounge, and drank, and ate, and talked for so long. It was something that Tor had never wanted to forget back then, and now, something he wished he couldn't remember. It progressed slowly. That was something Tor was thankful for. No matter what, he had made sure it was slow, and steady. By the time of the ambush, they still hadn't slept with each other. Then, as if the console had been reading him, it was there. The ambush. The deaths. And finally, the betrayal, and her attempt at redemption. Laughter rang out behind him, making Tor jump in surprise.
--- Her. It was her. "Hey there, Torrie. I can see you missed me." She grinned, while Tor felt his heart drop. Her voice was the same as usual, sing-songy, like a bird. "You are probably wondering what this all is, how I'm here?" She asked, resting a hand on his shoulder. Well, you’re on the USS Vita, on it’s destination to the planet Mors.” She chuckled, as Tor’s confusion showed. ”Course, not everyone is going to make it… Like me, or our friends, or our Captain, but maybe your new friends are gonna make it…” Her grin turned sinister, as Tor stood up, opening his mouth to try and… Well, he wasn’t sure what he was going to do if he would have spoken, but the sight he was seeing shocked him silent. Those who had been walking around, had suddenly been armed, and were taking aim at Maggie, Nira, Dune, anyone and everyone that has interacted with him, and all of them were looking at her. Still grinning, she turned to the armed men and women, and held up a hand, and somehow, Tor knew, if she lowered it, they would open fire… But he couldn’t stop it.
--- The scene had changed. It was almost unbelievable. People were lying everywhere. He couldn’t stop them. He was holding someone in his arms on the floor, but he couldn’t tell who. More people surrounded him, and consoles had flickered on and off, but the screen, one he hadn’t noticed, was functioning just fine. A giant planet, black against the vacuum of space, and giant red clouds swirling around, and the ship was heading straight for it, not slowing down. Tor tried to stand up, but he couldn’t… He couldn’t move his leg. Letting the person in his arms to fall, he began crawling over to the Captain’s seat, propping himself onto it, and watching the impending doom approach the ship… Before the bridge slowly changed. He wasn’t on the Phoenix. He was on the Salvator. Blood was everywhere. Bodies had piled up, but there were survivors this time… But they didn’t look alive. They looked as if their very spirits had vanished, as if everything that had made them alive had all left them, as the Salvator pulled away from a battle between the Ferengi ships, watching as their friends and loved ones sacrificed themselves to allow the others to escape, and the ship changed once more. Tor was sitting where Valdain had sat, upon the Arrinthe. Tal Shiar were all over the place, working as the Arrinthe pulled towards a planet. A cruel smile had covered Tor’s face, and he couldn’t see it, he didn’t know, but… As he looked into the screen, he saw his home, and his reflection… And saw his own twisted reflection in it, before a maniacal laugh, Valdain’s laughter, erupted everywhere, and Tor could only hear his own cries for help, underneath all the screams of laughter.
--- Shooting up in his bed, with a blistering headache, Tor wiped the sweat off his face, and rolled himself out of bed… Back into the sonic shower, back to changing his clothes, back to his old routine… But with the nightmare still with him, still clinging to him, worse than before. He would remember to take his medication. He couldn’t suffer this again. Stumbling out of his room, he headed to the hallway... He had to work. He had to get to the bridge.

Here he was hoping to stay as low-profile as possible, up until he delivered his congratulatory speech anyway, but here life was, intending to derail those plans. Unkindness, or a nudge forward in the right direction? A mix of both? He couldn't tell. But it would be rather rude to refuse, and he had never been one to turn down things such as this. He hence sent back his assent and pulled up human marriage ceremonial duties on his desktop monitor, now having two speeches to prepare. Among all the things the man was known for, speechmaker was one of them. He'd just have to hope that thr talent wouldn't fail him. (edited)

Generally it led to a person realising that they did need to talk after all... And then there was the approach. It meant that a person did not feel as if they were talking about themselves. Years of practice had made her a master of making people talk, even if the method was a little manipulative.
